awd_titl_txt: Singularities and Long Time Dynamics in Nonlinear Dispersive Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this project is to study the solutions to a wide class of equations that can best be described as nonlinear waves. These mathematical equations model a broad range of physical phenomena in our universe and even in our daily lives, including the water waves at the surface of our oceans and the quantum-mechanical interaction of multi-particle systems, as well as, on a broader scale, gravitational waves and their evolution in the proximity of black holes. The common feature in these models lies in the strength of the wave interactions, which drastically affects both their short-time and long-time behavior. Phenomena to be studied include both short-time breakdown of waves, as well as long-time persistence and/or dispersion and decay of waves. 

The objective of this project is to attack a broad array of challenging problems within the field of nonlinear dispersive equations.  The equations to be considered range from semilinear to fully nonlinear, and the types of properties to be investigated span from short-range to long-range behavior, from scattering to blow-up questions.   The research connects ideas and methods in partial differential equations to geometry, harmonic analysis, complex analysis, and microlocal analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The broad area of mathematics which covers the research supported by this grant is partial differential equations. The general objective here is to study the existence and uniqueness of solutions to a given equation, and then to investigate their properties. All physical phenomenas are described by appropriate partial differential equations, so carrying out this research allows us to gain insights and make predictions about the world we live in.

The class of equations studied in this project are evolution equations, where one seeks to understand how the state of a system varies in time. Further, they describe wave propagation of one type or another, where these waves travel with varying  speeds depending on their wave lenghts and on their background. Such equations are called dispersive equations. Finally,  in nearly all physical phenomena, waves which travel in different directions do interact; this makes the equations nonlinear, and represents the main challenge in their study. Thus, in a nutshell, the aim of this project has been to study nonlinear wave interactions.

There are several classes of nonlinear dispersive  problems which have been considered as part of this research, and which are briefly described in what follows.

1) The water waves equations,  which in the simplest setting describe the motion of the free surface of a body of water. The work here has investigated various aspects of this flow, including both the long time behavior of smooth waves, as well  as the short time interactions of rough waves. Due to the complexity of the water wave equations, another interesting  problem here is to derive good simplified model equations for this flow in various regimes, and then to understand the extent to which these model flows can be used to describe the behavior of the fully nonlinear equation. Many of these model problems belong to the class of completely integrable systems, which has been a secondary thrust of this research.

2) Geometric dispersive equations, such as Wave Maps, Yang-Mills or Schroedinger Maps, lie at the intersection of partial differential equations and geometry, and represent flows which evolve on interesting geometrical backgrounds. They are interesting both in themselves, and as model problems in general relativity and other areas. The main interest here during the grant period has been in the study of the long time behavior of these flows, and its connection to the chosen geometrical setting.


3) Quasilinear problems represent the most nonlinear models in partial differential equations, where not only the interactions of propagating waves are at stake, but also the background on which these waves propagate. Understanding  these flows in rough wave settings in several such equations has been another objective of this research.

4) Free boundary problems are flows which are restricted  to domains whose boundary is moving freely as well, as part of the flow. The water wave equations mentioned above are one such example. But there is also another such problem which was considered as part of this project, namely  the compressible Euler flow for a gas. One example to keep in mind here is a gaseous star, where the free boundary exactly delimits the gas region, and is always in motion.

All the research supported by this grant was cooperative, involving about fifteen collaborators ad different stages in their career, and including postdocs and graduate students. Raising the next generation of researchers has been a priority for the PI, who advised no less than nine graduate students and three postdocs during the grant period. Organizing research seminars, summer school programs and research programs were all part of the grant research activities.
